title: Soraka is one of the MOST boring champions to play against
body:

I feel that the rework to her Q, specifically the removal of the "sweet spot" was a really terrible mistake.
That sweet spot was hard to hit, and caused an interesting little minigame where Soraka tried to land perfect Qs to hit someone in that sweet spot, while the enemy tried to avoid being hit by the sweet spot.  Now, she can just spam it and doesn't really have to care about aiming it properly.

There's both much less opportunity for the Soraka player to show her skill, and for her opponents to use theirs to reduce her effectiveness.

> There's both much less opportunity for the Soraka player to show her skill, and for her opponents to use theirs to reduce her effectiveness.

But no Soraka ever actually tried to hit the sweet spot because it was so harrd to hit and not actually worth the difficulty. A moderate slow wasn't worth trying for and the damage increase was irrelevant because her damage is meaningless regardless of using her abilities perfectly. For the enemy players it was much more important to avoid being hit by the Q full stop than to avoid being hit by the empowered Q because the most important thing to avoid was Soraka getting health back, not the damage or the potential slow.

The sweet spot was removed because it was too impractical a mechanic for Soraka players to actively care about it (why would you focus on such a difficult to use slow/mediocre damage amp when you have much more powerful abilities that are significantly easier to use?) and the power of the Q being hidden behind something so difficult to utilise meant that it became a completely ignorable move altogether. Soraka cares a *lot* more about her Q now because it's more powerful in ways you actually care about and you can actually access that power with some level of reliability. 

When Q had the sweet spot mechanic, Soraka players never bothered trying to hit the opponent with it because it was just easier to sit back and avoid taking damage if you wanted to sustain yourself. It wasn't worth putting yourself in danger for a 10% (if not lower?) chance of a slow and a mild damage increase. Now that you know you'll get the slow and a boost to your healing off hitting Q, it's much easier to justify using it than it once was.

When I played Soraka, I always maxed Q first, and usually consistently bullied my opponents out of lane with it by hitting the sweet spot damage.

That felt like a much more healthy pattern than before.  Good damage if you could hit it, decent sustain but not that godlike since heal was only maxed second.

But I suppose most people didn't play her like that.  They just maxed heal and only used her Qs to get health back, rather than actually trying to damage her enemies.


Now I feel that her Q is just used as an extension to her healing, to make her heals stronger and keep herself healthy.  It feels less like making a choice between poke and healing, and less skilled overall because the ability is much easier to land at full effectiveness.

> [{quoted}](name=Nameless Voice,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=r7aaYlYe,comment-id=000400010000,timestamp=2016-04-24T13:09:00.016+0000)

Unfortunately you are a major outlier in how you played Soraka. For the vast majority of her playerbase, maxing W first and using Q only when you wanted health back was the ideal way to play her laning phase. Speaking as someone who played her a decent amount just before and after the pre-season, I maxed W first exclusively for burst healing and had no interest whatsoever in poking the enemy out of lane - I could do that with significantly more ease with someone like Sona or Zyra.

Perhaps if they'd increased the sweet spot size and made her heal bigger if they hit the sweet spot, people would have been more willing to take advantage of her Q, but removing the sweet spot altogether and making the wider part of the skillshot more impactful was probably a more fool-proof solution.

The problem there was that both Soraka's self-heal and her ally-heal were both on W, so maxing W first gave you both sustain for yourself and your ally.

They shifted that around in her rework so that you need to max Q to get the self-healing required to refill your own health.  That alone would have shifted her more towards needing to max Q first and use Q regularly.

With her current state, I'd like to see the sweet spot introduced, and both the healing and the damage of the spell changed to be lower for non-sweet-spot and higher for hitting the sweet spot.

Good luck sweetspotting Q's against an opponent that moves faster than Eggnivia.

Personally, I'd rather Soraka be able to spam Q's than have to aim them perfectly because it at least means I can engage on her when she tried to poke. If she can't land the sweetspot consistently (and no Soraka except maybe her dedicated mains can land the sweetspot consistently) then she has no reason to use her Q, and if she has no reason to use her Q then her optimal strategy is to buy massive amounts of health regeneration to offset her W's healing cost and do nothing but heal all laning phase. That's even less fun than a Soraka that spams Q all game.

They're playing around with different ways to nerf her for next patch, since her win rate has crept up significantly since the mini-rework that promoted more interactivity. The problem isn't her healing output, either baseline or AP-scaling. It isn't her self-healing from her Q, the slow applied by her Q, or the tertiary effects applied by Ardent Censer or the upcoming Athene's Unholy grail.

The problem is Ancient Coin.

Fundamentally, she's balanced around her W's health costs. She has mana costs that prevent her from spamming without a care in the world, yes, but they're hardly prohibitive and they'll be even less of a factor after the MYMU and the new items get rolled out. As a result of being balanced around %maxHP health costs, she has a lot of somewhat unusual interaction with stats. She loathes bonus health, because it increases her costs without granting her anything significant in return, and she loves sources of regeneration and healing, because they *directly* reduce the windows of vulnerability she has to expose herself to in order to keep going.

It's that last part that's the key.

She's amazingly frustrating to play against because when you start to win lane against her - say you're good at dodging her Q - she isn't forced to keep toying with you. She just backs off, way out of poke range, and plays passively for half a minute and regains half of her health via passive regeneration and Ancient Coin's health return.

You want to see a far more fun lane opponent? Try playing against Soraka using FQC instead of Ancient Coin. She's rewarded for skirmishing, landing Q, harassing with E, and can't offset bad play (taking way more poke than she gives) by hanging back at tower and leeching health from dying minions.

We've seen the problem late game with Warmog's Armor. Aynthing that gives her massively increased health return breaks her risk/reward payoff structure. She's only balanced when her Q is her primary source of health restoration, and anything outside that will only make her frustrating and overpowered.

**TL;DR: Soraka is balanced around Q regeneration and powerful item-based healing from Ancient Coin and Warmog's Armor causes problems.**

Her or her adc aren't targets you can wear down over time.  Anything with a lot of burst or long engage does quite well against her (blitz, annie, braum, Nami, Leona, an experienced thresh.)

Same goes for her opposing adc.  Draven, Quinn, Graves are all great picks.  Something that can push out a lot of damage on a short amount of time.
That's why she's still getting more nerfs, even though Riot hinted that GW will soon apply to ally healing too.

As a Soraka main, there's several ways of countering her. Get a burst mage that can pop squishies easily without any ability for Soraka to sustain up/heal allies, get lock-down champions for botlane (Braum, Leona, Nautilus etc.) and go all in.

With Soraka you want to separate her from her adc. Try to position so she can't run in without risting major damage, a Soraka player with less experience will be a bot flustered by this.

She's fine, honestly. I think she was more enjoyable for me last season when everyone hated her and told me not tp pick her, only for me to hard carry games. Now people just sigh and shake their head at the banana queen being locked in. Much sadness...
